On 2/3/06, Jason Rogers <jacaetevha@...> wrote:
>
> > Code that u=
ses both will always be safer than code that only uses one of
> > these.
> =
That is a very striking statement. Are you saying that (in your opinion)
> =
static languages are inherently safer than dynamic languages?


That's not =
exactly what I said.  I was simply pointing out that in order to
make my co=
de safer, I will always pick an approach that verifies A and B
over one tha=
t only verifies A.  Seems to be simple common sense.

Having said that, you=
r question made me wonder...  It's pretty easy to come
up with examples of =
bugs that will be caught by the compiler but that might
slip through in a d=
ynamic language.

I am trying to think of an opposite example, but right no=
w, I'm coming up
empty, which tends to make me want to answer "yes" to your=
 question. But
I'll think a bit more about it.

Very interesting question a=
nyway.
